Literature Review: Quantum many-body scars are a phenomenon where certain species of stable quasiparticles can exist throughout the energy spectrum of a many-body system. This is a result of the proliferation of decay channels at higher energies, which can lead to the formation of scars. These scars can give rise to unusual nonequilibrium phenomena, including many-body revivals and nonthermal stationary states. In this review, we will discuss the physics of quantum many-body scars via a simple yet comprehensive example, the spin-1 XY model. We will also place our discussion in the broader context of symmetry-based constructions of many-body scar states, projector embeddings, and Hilbert space fragmentation. We will conclude with a summary of experimental progress and theoretical puzzles.
